stream_context.summary: Kaze brainstorms and live-models the visual identity and layout for Course 11, a new Bowser-themed oil rig level, after scrapping its previous volcano theme. The process involves iterating on large mountain/spire designs and planning out the level's mission structure. Kaze also revisits Course 1 to plan improvements to its opening section.

development_findings.summary: Course 11's theme has been completely changed from a volcano to a Bowser-themed oil rig and airship production facility.
development_findings.quote: The whole volcano theme is gone now we want it to be something like this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze states his design philosophy that creative ideas must serve a purpose and solve a specific design problem, rather than being random additions.
development_findings.quote: Designing something is not just about coming up with ideas, it's about solving whatever problem you have in design.

development_findings.summary: The level names follow a strict convention of being alliterations, rhymes, or another memorable stylistic device, such as the working title "Frantic Fleet Factory" for Course 11.
For Course 11, Kaze is deviating from his usual level design process by creating a library of assets first and then assembling them, rather than building the layout from a holistic plan.
development_findings.quote: It's probably best we just make a few random assets for now, and then just see how we can combine them to look good. This is usually not how we make levels, but for this level, it might be the best.

development_findings.summary: Kaze outlined a multi-mission structure for Course 11, involving a worker strike that grants access to a crane used to destroy a giant Bowser statue.
Kaze plans to redesign the first star of Course 1 to add more verticality and better guide the player through the level, making for a more substantial introduction.
development_findings.quote: And then you just spin on top of the windmill and the star kind of just takes you around the whole level like that, with a lot of vertical platforming.

development_findings.summary: Multi-language support is likely for the game, driven by the persistent efforts of a community translator named Rionu.
After experimenting with several styles, Kaze settled on a blocky, Mario-esque mountain design for Course 11 that is visually fitting, low-poly, and clearly communicates walkable surfaces.
development_findings.quote: I finally have the thing that I want... This is gonna look very Mario esque as well which is why I like this idea so much and there will be no confusion about where you can and can't stand.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels that many modern games lack a sense of freedom and discovery, describing the experience as passively following a pre-determined checklist rather than actively playing.
context_findings.quote: I feel like there are so many video games where there is no solution right off the bat and I know that I just have to follow these instructions that I have already predefined like months ago to solve the game and it's like I'm not even playing, I'm actually just following instructions I've laid out myself.

context_findings.summary: Kaze comments on the risk of another ROM hack releasing close to a major Nintendo launch, noting both the marketing challenges and the increased likelihood of legal action from Nintendo.
context_findings.quote: Nintendo also has a habit of going after ROM hack right after they release their own games so that is a pretty ballsy move to do.

context_findings.summary: The project's working title is "Return to Yoshi's Island 64," but Kaze is concerned it may not be easily searchable.
Kaze mentions a personal outing with his wife, Zeina, where they made a terrarium, showing a glimpse into their life outside of game development.
context_findings.quote: I actually touched grass yesterday. Me and Zeina, we went out and we made a cool... we made a terrarium in a closed jar.

zeina.summary: Kaze is waiting on animations from Zeina to complete the game's end cutscene, indicating a key dependency in the project workflow.
zeina.quote: I still also need to do the end cutscene, but I was waiting for the animations for Zeina first. They took a while.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze went on an outing to build a terrarium together, highlighting their personal relationship.

key_stories.title: Designing the Foundational Mountains for Course 11
key_stories.summary: While designing the core landscape for the oil rig level, Kaze cycled through several rejected ideas for the large rock spires. A breakthrough occurred when a community member suggested a blocky, Mario-esque mountain style, which Kaze adopted as it solved the aesthetic and platforming challenges.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to establish the foundational geography for Course 11, an oil rig level. He struggled to find a visual style for the large rock formations that was thematically appropriate, visually interesting, and functional for platforming.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed and prototyped several ideas for the level's large structures, including realistic rocks and mountains inspired by New Super Mario Bros. He rejected these due to aesthetic mismatches and gameplay concerns. The breakthrough came when a chat member provided an image of stylized, blocky mountains, which Kaze immediately identified as the right solution and began modeling.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze adopted a blocky, stylized mountain design inspired by a community member's suggestion. This new direction solved the visual and gameplay problems, allowing him to move forward with the level's layout.
key_stories.key_quote: I finally have the thing that I want... This is gonna look very Mario esque as well which is why I like this idea so much and there will be no confusion about where you can and can't stand.

key_stories.title: Revisiting and Improving Course 1's First Star
key_stories.summary: Identifying the first star path in Course 1 as too simplistic, Kaze devised a plan to expand it. By adding new platforms and repositioning the windmill, he aims to create a more dynamic and vertical introduction to the game.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt that the path for the first star in Course 1 was too short and linear, failing to provide an adequate introduction to the game's mechanics and scale.
key_stories.process: After being prompted by a chat comment, Kaze re-evaluated the opening of Course 1. He decided to add a new platforming section involving a tree and reposition the level's windmill to create a spinning platform element, extending the path significantly.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze formulated a new, more complex path for the star that incorporates more verticality and guides the player on a tour of the level, creating a more robust and engaging opening experience.
key_stories.key_quote: Initially what it was, is that there was just a line to get to the end there and that star was like way too short. So I added a bit more to it, but I was thinking we're going to add something else.
